natural problem: How many different $4\times 4$ arrays whose entries are all 1's and -1's have the property that the sum of the entries in each row is 0 and the sum of the entries in each column is 0?
natural solution: The problem is asking us for all configurations of $4\times 4$ grids with 2 1's and 2 -1's in each row and column.

We do casework upon the first two columns: The first two columns share no two numbers in the same row. There are ${4\choose2} = 6$ ways to pick two 1's in the first column, and the second column is determined.

For the third and fourth columns, no two numbers can be in the same row (to make the sum of each row 0), so again there are ${4\choose 2}$ ways. This gives $6^2 = 36$. The first two columns share one number in the same row.

There are ${4\choose 1} = 4$ ways to pick the position of the shared 1, then ${3\choose 2} = 3$ ways to pick the locations for the next two 1s, and then $2$ ways to orient the 1s. For the third and fourth columns, the two rows with shared 1s or -1s are fixed, so the only things that can be changed is the orientation of the mixed rows, in $2$ ways.

This gives $4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 = 48$. The first two columns share two numbers in the same row. There are ${4\choose 2} = 6$ ways to pick the position of the shared 1s. Everything is then fixed.
Adding these cases up, we get $36 + 48 + 6 = \boxed{90}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes array :: "(nat × nat) ⇒ int"
assumes h0 : "∀i. i < 4 ⟶ sum (λj. array (i, j)) {0..3} = 0"
and h1 : "∀j. j < 4 ⟶ sum (λi. array (i, j)) {0..3} = 0"
and h2 : "∀i j. (i < 4 ∧ j < 4) ⟶ (array (i, j) = 1 ∨ array (i, j) = -1)"
shows  "card {array. P array} = 90"

 For the third and fourth columns, no two numbers can be in the same row (to make the sum of each row 0), so again there are ${4\choose 2}$ ways. This gives $6^2 = 36$. The first two columns share one number in the same row.
 There are ${4\choose 1} = 4$ ways to pick the position of the shared 1, then ${3\choose 2} = 3$ ways to pick the locations for the next two 1s, and then $2$ ways to orient the 1s. theorem
fixes array :: "(nat × nat) ⇒ int"
assumes h0 : "∀i. i < 4 ⟶ sum (λj. array (i, j)) {0..3} = 0"

assumes h0 : "length arrays = 4"

For the third and fourth columns, the two rows with shared 1s or -1s are fixed, so the only things that can be changed is the orientation of the mixed rows, in $2$ ways.

theorem count_4x4_arrays:
fixes count_arrays :: nat
assumes h0 : "count_arrays = card {A :: (int^4^4). (\<forall>i. (\<Sum>j. A $ i $ j) = 0) \<and> (\<forall>j. (\<Sum>i. A $ i $ j) = 0) \<and> (\<forall>i j. A $ i $ j = 1 \<or> A $ i $ j = -1)}"
shows  "count_arrays = 90"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

 We do casework upon the first two columns: The first two columns share no two numbers in the same row. There are ${4\choose2} = 6$ ways to pick two 1's in the first column, and the second column is determined.
 For the third and fourth columns, no two numbers can be in the same row (to make the sum of each row 0), so again there are ${4\choose 2}$ ways. This gives $6^2 = 36$. The first two columns share one number in the same row.
 There are ${4\choose 1} = 4$ ways to pick the position of the shared 1, then ${3\choose 2} = 3$ ways to pick the locations for the next two 1s, and then $2$ ways to orient the 1s. For the third and fourth columns, the two rows with shared 1s or -1s are fixed, so the only things that can be changed is the orientation of the mixed rows, in $2$ ways.
 This gives $4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 = 48$. The first two columns share two numbers in the same row. There are ${4\choose 2} = 6$ ways to pick the position of the shared 1s. Everything is then fixed.
 Adding these cases up, we get $36 + 48 + 6 = \boxed{90}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i < 4. (\<Sum>j<4. array i j) = 0"
and h1 : "\<forall>j < 4. (\<Sum>i<4. array i j) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> (array i j = 1 \<or> array i j = -1)"
shows  "card {A. \<forall>i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> (A i j = 1 \<or> A i j = -1)} = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a 4x4 grid with each cell containing either 1 or -1. How many such grids have the property that the sum of the elements in each row and each column is 0? The final answer is 90.
